subject: Re: [samuraihistory] firearm training + LEEDS ROYAL ARMOURIES

Hi Folks,

I spoke to Ian a few months back, he's still with us, but is rea=
lly deep
in to his work at the armouries. Ian is most definitely into firea=
rms,
right down to having reproduced a replica of a rare Japanese wheellock=

pistol for himself. And I concur with Paul, he is a terrifically helpful
c=
hap. Without his help our samurai re-enactment project, wouldn't have
even =
got off the starting blocks. Not only did he spend a day with us
studying t=
he Snows Hill collection, plus numerous trips to see his own,
he lent our a=
rmourer one of his own dou to copy, and gave us a lot of
the "insiders" kno=
wledge essential to reproducing high quality replica
arms, armour and cloth=
ing. We owe that man a lot:-)

Also as I mentioned in an earlier post, it w=
as he, together with Stephen
Turnbull who were responsible for the presenta=
tion of all that new stuff
on the evolution of Japanese firearms at the Arm=
ouries a few years back,
blowing the myth of the European responsibility fo=
r the introduction of
firearms to the Japanese out of the water, so to spea=
k. 

Yours

Dean
***

ld told=A0 me to search out

an's one on

sleeves.

ell when I have had questions to ask.
